Her Majesty’s a pretty nice girl
 But she doesn’t have a lot to say
 Her Majesty’s a pretty nice girl
 But she changes from day to day

This whimsical little ditty provides comic relief to contrast the solemnity of the Abbey Road Medley; although, it was originally supposed to be a component of the piece. The lyrics are silly in their irreverence—on one hand, Paul calls The Queen “her majesty,” but he also treats her like he would any other girl.

On the other hand, as evidenced by the latter half of the song, perhaps this irreverence is a form of intimacy, and he finds her to be endearing.



The Beatles meeting the Queen during their November 1963 ‘Royal Variety’ performance.
